H0.text: Trees and grass help to prevent a collapse of the underlying sediment when a mining company removes the plants and layers of soil and rock above a coal deposit, extracts the coal, and then restores the area by returning soil and rock, covering it with topsoil, and planting trees and grass.

H1.text: Limit the types of pollutants that can enter the soil is what trees and grass do after a mining company removes plants and layers of soil and rock above the coal deposit, takes the coal, and then returns soil and rock, covers it with topsoil, and plants trees and grass.

H2.text: Increase water absorption by the replaced sediments is what trees and grass help to achieve when a mining company removes the plants and layers of soil and rock above the coal deposit, extracts the coal, and then returns soil and rock, covers it with a layer of topsoil, and plants trees and grass.

H3.text: Reduce soil erosion and provide new habitat for animals is the benefit achieved by the trees and grass that the mining company plants after restoring the site with soil, rock, and a topsoil layer following the removal of vegetation and overburden for coal extraction.

A4.text: The intact forest floor, with its layers of leaf litter and organic matter, is still able to absorb the impact of the rainfall.

A5.text: The removal of vegetation increases the rate of surface erosion.

A6.text: Higher quantities of leaf litter hold higher humidity levels, a key factor for the establishment of plants.

A7.text: The use of stock exclosure and natural regeneration revegetation techniques was applied to degraded paddocks, leading to successful revegetation.
